Germany: Germany has over 1,500 breweries and is famous for its beer purity law from 1516.
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, reuniting East and West Germany.
Germany is home to the world's largest beer festival, Oktoberfest.
France: France is the most visited country in the world with over 89 million tourists annually.
The Eiffel Tower was originally intended to be temporary and was built for the 1889 World's Fair.
France has won the most Nobel Prizes in Literature of any country.
Spain: Spain has more than 3,000 hours of sunshine per year.
The Spanish language is spoken by over 500 million people worldwide.
Spain is home to the world's oldest restaurant, Sobrino de Botín, opened in 1725.
Italy: Italy has more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other country.
The piano was invented in Italy around 1700 by Bartolomeo Cristofori.
Italy produces over 350 types of pasta.
Poland: Poland is home to 17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The Polish language uses 32 letters in its alphabet.
Poland has one of the world's largest castle complexes, Malbork Castle.
Netherlands: The Netherlands has more museums per square mile than any other country.
About 26% of the Netherlands is below sea level.
The Netherlands produces 4.3 billion tulip bulbs annually.
Belgium: Belgium produces over 220,000 tons of chocolate per year.
Brussels is home to the headquarters of both NATO and the European Union.
Belgium has three official languages: Dutch, French, and German.
Switzerland: Switzerland has four official languages: German, French, Italian, and Romansh.
The Swiss consume more chocolate per capita than any other nation.
Switzerland has remained neutral in every war since 1815.
Austria: Austria is the birthplace of classical music composers Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss.
The Sound of Music was filmed in Austria, specifically in Salzburg.
Czech Republic: Prague, the capital, is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires'.
The Czech Republic consumes the most beer per capita in the world.
The word 'robot' comes from the Czech word 'robota' meaning forced labor.
Hungary: Hungary has 13 wine regions and produces excellent wines.
The Hungarian language is unrelated to any other European language.
Budapest has the largest thermal water cave system in the world.
Slovakia: Slovakia has more castles per capita than any other country.
The geographical center of Europe is located in Slovakia.
Slovakia is home to the world's largest castle complex by area.
Slovenia: Slovenia is one of the most forested countries in Europe with 60% forest coverage.
Lake Bled in Slovenia has a church on an island that can only be reached by boat.
Slovenia has over 10,000 caves, including the famous Postojna Cave.
Croatia: Croatia has over 1,200 islands along its coastline.
The necktie (cravat) was invented in Croatia.
Croatia is home to the world's smallest town, Hum, with only 30 residents.
Serbia: Serbia is one of the world's largest producers of raspberries.
The Serbian language can be written in both Cyrillic and Latin scripts.
Serbia has 5 national parks and numerous nature reserves.
Bosnia and Herzegovina: Bosnia and Herzegovina has three official languages: Bosnian, Croatian, and Serbian.
The country is famous for its traditional coffee culture.
Montenegro: Montenegro means 'Black Mountain' in most European languages.
It's one of the youngest countries in the world, gaining independence in 2006.
Montenegro has 117 beaches along its 295km coastline.
Albania: Albania is home to over 750,000 bunkers built during the communist era.
The Albanian language is unique and not closely related to any other language.
Albania has both Mediterranean and Alpine climates.
North Macedonia: North Macedonia is the birthplace of Mother Teresa.
The country has over 1,100 plant species, many of which are endemic.
Ohrid Lake is one of the oldest and deepest lakes in Europe.
Bulgaria: Bulgaria is famous for its rose oil production, used in perfumes worldwide.
The Cyrillic alphabet was developed in Bulgaria.
Bulgaria has over 40,000 ancient burial mounds called tumuli.
Romania: Romania is home to Bran Castle, often associated with Dracula.
The Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest is the second-largest building in the world.
Romania has the largest population of brown bears in Europe.
Moldova: Moldova has the largest wine cellar in the world, stretching for 200km underground.
It's the least visited country in Europe, making it a hidden gem.
Moldova is landlocked between Romania and Ukraine.
Ukraine: Ukraine is the largest country entirely within Europe.
The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone has become an unexpected wildlife sanctuary.
Ukraine is known as the 'breadbasket of Europe' for its fertile farmland.
Belarus: Belarus is known as the 'lungs of Europe' due to its vast forests.
The country has over 20,000 rivers and 11,000 lakes.
Belarus is famous for its traditional wooden architecture.
Lithuania: Lithuania was the first Soviet republic to declare independence in 1990.
The country has a unique tradition of cross-crafting recognized by UNESCO.
Lithuania has the fastest public Wi-Fi in the world.
Latvia: Latvia has the widest waterfall in Europe, Ventas Rumba.
The country has over 12,000 rivers and 3,000 small lakes.
Riga's Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Estonia: Estonia is one of the most digitally advanced countries in the world.
Estonia has over 2,000 islands in the Baltic Sea.
Finland: Finland has more saunas than cars - about 3.3 million saunas for 5.5 million people.
The Northern Lights can be seen in Finland about 200 nights per year.
Finland is the happiest country in the world according to multiple studies.
Sweden: Sweden has not been at war for over 200 years.
IKEA, H&M, Volvo, and Spotify all originated in Sweden.
Sweden has more than 267,000 islands larger than 5 square meters.
Norway: Norway has the world's longest road tunnel, the Lærdal Tunnel, at 24.5 km.
The country has over 1,000 fjords along its coastline.
Norway is home to the midnight sun phenomenon in summer.
Denmark: Denmark is consistently ranked as one of the happiest countries in the world.
LEGO was invented in Denmark in 1958.
Denmark has more than 7,000 kilometers of coastline.
Iceland: Iceland runs almost entirely on renewable energy from geothermal and hydroelectric sources.
There are no mosquitoes in Iceland.
Iceland has more than 130 volcanic mountains.
Ireland: Ireland is known as the 'Emerald Isle' due to its lush green landscape.
The shamrock is Ireland's national symbol.
Ireland has produced four Nobel Prize winners in Literature.
United Kingdom: The UK has no place that is more than 75 miles from the sea.
London's Big Ben is not actually the name of the clock tower, but the bell inside it.
Portugal: Portugal is the oldest nation state in Europe, founded in 1143.
The Portuguese language is spoken by over 250 million people worldwide.
Portugal produces half of the world's cork.
Turkey: Turkey is the only country that spans two continents, Europe and Asia.
Turkish coffee was the first coffee ever brewed, and Turkey gave coffee to Europe.
The city of Istanbul was once the capital of both the Byzantine and Ottoman empires.
Greece: Greece has more than 6,000 islands, but only 227 are inhabited.
Greece is the birthplace of democracy, philosophy, and the Olympic Games.
Greek is one of the oldest recorded living languages, with 34 centuries of written records.
Cyprus: Cyprus is the third largest island in the Mediterranean Sea.
The island is famous for being the birthplace of Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love.
Cyprus has 340 days of sunshine per year.
Malta: Malta is one of the smallest countries in the world, smaller than many cities.
The Maltese language is the only Semitic language written in Latin script.
Malta has three UNESCO World Heritage Sites despite its small size.
Russia: Russia spans 11 time zones, more than any other country.
The Trans-Siberian Railway is the longest railway line in the world at 9,289 km.
Russia has more than 100,000 rivers and 2 million lakes.
China: China has the world's largest population with over 1.4 billion people.
The Great Wall of China is over 13,000 miles long.
China invented paper, gunpowder, the compass, and printing.
Japan: Japan consists of 6,852 islands, though only about 430 are inhabited.
Japan has more than 3 million vending machines.
Mount Fuji is Japan's highest mountain and an active volcano.
India: India is the world's largest democracy with over 900 million eligible voters.
India has 22 official languages and over 1,600 spoken languages.
The game of chess was invented in India.
South Korea: South Korea has the fastest internet speeds in the world.
Taekwondo originated in South Korea and is now practiced worldwide.
South Korea has more than 3,000 islands.
Thailand: Thailand is the only Southeast Asian country never to have been colonized.
Bangkok's real name is 169 letters long in Thai.
Thailand is home to the world's smallest mammal, the bumblebee bat.
Vietnam: Vietnam is the world's largest producer of cashew nuts.
The country has 54 ethnic groups with distinct languages and cultures.
Ha Long Bay has over 1,600 limestone islands and islets.
Indonesia: Indonesia is the world's largest archipelago with over 17,000 islands.
Indonesia is home to the world's largest flower, the Rafflesia.
The country has more active volcanoes than any other nation.
Malaysia: Malaysia is one of the world's 17 megadiverse countries.
The Petronas Twin Towers were the world's tallest buildings from 1998 to 2004.
Malaysia has 13 states and 3 federal territories.
Singapore: Singapore is both a city and a country, making it a city-state.
The country has four official languages: English, Malay, Mandarin, and Tamil.
Singapore has the world's tallest indoor waterfall at Changi Airport.
Philippines: Filipino and English are the official languages, but over 180 languages are spoken.
The Philippines is the world's second-largest archipelago.
Australia: Australia is the only country that is also a continent.
Australia has more species of venomous snakes than any other country.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system.
New Zealand: New Zealand has more sheep than people - about 5 sheep per person.
The country was the first to give women the right to vote in 1893.
New Zealand has no native land mammals except for bats.
Brazil: Brazil is home to 60% of the Amazon rainforest.
Brazil has won the FIFA World Cup 5 times, more than any other country.
The country has the world's largest carnival celebration in Rio de Janeiro.
Argentina: Argentina is famous for its tango dance and music.
The country is the world's second-largest producer of beef.
Argentina has the highest literacy rate in South America at 98%.
Chile: Chile is the world's longest and narrowest country.
The Atacama Desert in Chile is the driest place on Earth.
Chile produces some of the world's finest wines.
Peru: Peru is home to Machu Picchu, one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
The country has over 3,000 varieties of potatoes.
Peru has 12 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
Colombia: Colombia is the world's leading producer of emeralds.
The country is named after Christopher Columbus.
Colombia has the second-highest biodiversity in the world.
Venezuela: Venezuela has the world's largest oil reserves.
Angel Falls in Venezuela is the world's highest waterfall.
The country has won more international beauty pageants than any other.
Ecuador: Ecuador is named after the equator, which runs through the country.
The Galápagos Islands belong to Ecuador and inspired Darwin's theory of evolution.
Ecuador uses the US dollar as its official currency.
Bolivia: Bolivia has two capital cities: La Paz and Sucre.
The country has the world's largest salt flat, Salar de Uyuni.
Bolivia is one of only two landlocked countries in South America.
Paraguay: Paraguay is one of only two landlocked countries in South America.
The country has two official languages: Spanish and Guaraní.
Paraguay is known as the 'Heart of South America' due to its central location.
Uruguay: Uruguay was the first country to legalize same-sex marriage in South America.
The country has one of the highest literacy rates in the world.
Uruguay is known for its progressive social policies.
Guyana: Guyana is the only English-speaking country in South America.
The country has one of the highest suicide rates in the world.
Guyana means 'Land of Many Waters' in the indigenous language.
Suriname: Suriname is the smallest country in South America.
Dutch is the official language of Suriname.
About 80% of Suriname is covered by rainforest.
Mexico: Mexico has 67 national languages, with Spanish being the most widely spoken.
The country is home to the world's largest pyramid by volume, the Great Pyramid of Cholula.
Mexico gave the world chocolate, vanilla, and chili peppers.
United States: The United States has no official national language at the federal level.
Alaska has more coastline than all other US states combined.
The US has 63 national parks protecting diverse ecosystems.
Canada: Canada has the world's longest coastline at over 202,000 kilometers.
The country has two official languages: English and French.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined.
Egypt: Egypt is home to the only surviving wonder of the ancient world, the Great Pyramid of Giza.
The Nile River, the world's longest river, flows through Egypt.
Ancient Egyptians invented paper, ink, and the 365-day calendar.
South Africa: The country is home to the world's largest diamond mine.
South Africa has three capital cities: Cape Town, Pretoria, and Bloemfontein.
Nigeria: Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa with over 200 million people.
The country has over 500 indigenous languages.
Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer.
Kenya: Kenya is famous for its long-distance runners who dominate international marathons.
The country is home to the Great Migration of wildebeest and zebras.
Kenya has 47 counties and over 40 different ethnic groups.
Morocco: Morocco is the only African country with both Atlantic and Mediterranean coastlines.
The country is famous for its traditional handicrafts, especially carpets and pottery.
Morocco has been ruled by the same royal family for over 350 years.
Algeria: Algeria is the largest country in Africa by land area.
The Sahara Desert covers more than 80% of Algeria.
Algeria has seven UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
Tunisia: Tunisia was the birthplace of the Arab Spring in 2010.
The country has some of the best-preserved Roman ruins in the world.
Tunisia is the smallest country in North Africa.
Libya: Libya has the largest oil reserves in Africa.
The country is mostly desert, with the Sahara covering 90% of its territory.
Libya was once part of the Roman Empire and has many ancient ruins.
Sudan: Sudan was the largest country in Africa before South Sudan's independence in 2011.
The Blue and White Nile rivers meet in Sudan's capital, Khartoum.
Sudan has more pyramids than Egypt, with over 200 ancient pyramids.
Ethiopia: Ethiopia is the only African country never to have been fully colonized.
The country follows a unique calendar with 13 months.
Ethiopia is considered the birthplace of coffee.
Ghana: Ghana was the first African country to gain independence from European colonial rule.
The country is the world's second-largest producer of cocoa.
Ghana has more than 100 ethnic groups speaking over 250 languages.
